clusters.title: Jamaica in path of 'life-threatening' category five Hurricane Melissa

bullet_summary: Reported by BBC World, CBS News, Reuters Top News and others

items.title: Jamaica in path of 'life-threatening' category five Hurricane Melissa
items.standfirst: Melissa, which has already been blamed for the deaths of four people, could become the strongest hurricane ever to hit Jamaica.
items.content: Melissa, which has already been blamed for the deaths of four people, could become the strongest hurricane ever to hit Jamaica.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa threatens to bring catastrophic flooding to Jamaica
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa strengthened into a Category 5 storm on Monday, unleashing torrential rain and threatening to bring catastrophic flooding to the northern Caribbean.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa strengthened into a Category 5 storm on Monday, unleashing torrential rain and threatening to bring catastrophic flooding to the northern Caribbean.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa is a mighty Category 5 storm in the Caribbean
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa strengthened into a Category 5 could and could bring "catastrophic" flash flooding and landslides to Jamaica, Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
items.content: Hurricane Melissa strengthened into a Category 5 could and could bring "catastrophic" flash flooding and landslides to Jamaica, Haiti and the Dominican Republic.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa begins lashing Jamaica as 'catastrophic' Category 5 storm
Jamaicans take shelter as Hurricane Melissa bears down as category 5 storm
items.standfirst: Landfall is not expected until Tuesday but high winds have already felled trees and caused power cuts on the islandHurricane Melissa – follow latest updates liveJamaicans have started to take shelter from Hurricane Melissa as high winds topple trees and cause power cuts ahead of the category 5 storm making landfall on Tuesday.The slow-moving giant, the strongest hurricane to hit the island since records began in 1851, is increasing in intensity and forecast to linger over the island. Authorities fear it will unleash catastrophic flooding, landslides and extensive infrastructure damage. Continue reading...
items.content: Landfall is not expected until Tuesday but high winds have already felled trees and caused power cuts on the islandHurricane Melissa – follow latest updates liveJamaicans have started to take shelter from Hurricane Melissa as high winds topple trees and cause power cuts ahead of the category 5 storm making landfall on Tuesday.The slow-moving giant, the strongest hurricane to hit the island since records began in 1851, is increasing in intensity and forecast to linger over the island. Authorities fear it will unleash catastrophic flooding, landslides and extensive infrastructure damage. Continue reading...

items.title: Warming oceans probably fueling Hurricane Melissa’s rapid intensification
items.standfirst: Climate scientists have long warned that warming oceans are making explosive storm development more commonHurricane Melissa live updatesThe extraordinary intensification of Hurricane Melissa, set to be one of the strongest storms to ever hit Jamaica, is probably a symptom of the rapid heating of the world’s oceans, scientists have said.Melissa was a tropical storm on Saturday, before exploding in strength to a category 4 hurricane early on Sunday. The storm’s winds escalated from 70mph to 140mph in just a day, one of the fastest intensifications on record in the Atlantic Ocean.The Associated Press contributed reporting Continue reading...
items.content: Climate scientists have long warned that warming oceans are making explosive storm development more commonHurricane Melissa live updatesThe extraordinary intensification of Hurricane Melissa, set to be one of the strongest storms to ever hit Jamaica, is probably a symptom of the rapid heating of the world’s oceans, scientists have said.Melissa was a tropical storm on Saturday, before exploding in strength to a category 4 hurricane early on Sunday. The storm’s winds escalated from 70mph to 140mph in just a day, one of the fastest intensifications on record in the Atlantic Ocean.The Associated Press contributed reporting Continue reading...

items.title: Hurricane Melissa: Where and when will it make landfall in Jamaica?
items.standfirst: Melissa has strengthened into a major Category 5 storm. Here's what that means.
items.content: Melissa has strengthened into a major Category 5 storm. Here's what that means.

items.title: Weather tracker: Jamaica braces for its most powerful hurricane as Melissa reaches category 5
items.standfirst: Record-breaking hurricane expected to make landfall on Tuesday with 160mph winds, while New Zealand reels from storm damageHurricane Melissa – follow latest updates liveThe Caribbean is bracing for Hurricane Melissa, one of the most powerful to ever strike the region. Melissa began as a cluster of thunderstorms off the coast of west Africa, which travelled west and developed into a depression, reaching tropical storm status to the north of Venezuela on 21 October. Rapid intensification over the weekend strengthened Melissa to category 4 as it slowly meandered west through the Caribbean Sea.Melissa reached category 5 intensity on Monday morning with sustained winds of 160mph (257km/h). Melissa is forecast to take a turn to the north-east towards Jamaica on Monday afternoon, making landfall on Tuesday by about midday, maintaining it’s current strength, which would make it the strongest of only five hurricanes ever recorded to hit Jamaica directly. Continue reading...
items.content: Record-breaking hurricane expected to make landfall on Tuesday with 160mph winds, while New Zealand reels from storm damageHurricane Melissa – follow latest updates liveThe Caribbean is bracing for Hurricane Melissa, one of the most powerful to ever strike the region. Melissa began as a cluster of thunderstorms off the coast of west Africa, which travelled west and developed into a depression, reaching tropical storm status to the north of Venezuela on 21 October. Rapid intensification over the weekend strengthened Melissa to category 4 as it slowly meandered west through the Caribbean Sea.Melissa reached category 5 intensity on Monday morning with sustained winds of 160mph (257km/h). Melissa is forecast to take a turn to the north-east towards Jamaica on Monday afternoon, making landfall on Tuesday by about midday, maintaining it’s current strength, which would make it the strongest of only five hurricanes ever recorded to hit Jamaica directly. Continue reading...

items.title: Hurricane Melissa intensifies to Category 5, threatens Jamaica with 'catastrophic' flooding
items.standfirst: Hurricane Melissa intensified to a powerful Category 5 early Monday as forecasters warned the storm would cause catastrophic flash flooding, life-threatening landslides and extremely strong winds across the Caribbean
items.content: Hurricane Melissa intensified to a powerful Category 5 early Monday as forecasters warned the storm would cause catastrophic flash flooding, life-threatening landslides and extremely strong winds across the Caribbean

ai_summary: Hurricane Melissa intensified into a Category 5 storm, posing a threat to Jamaica.
The storm could bring catastrophic flooding and landslides to the region.
High winds have already caused power outages and toppled trees in Jamaica.
Scientists suggest warming oceans may be fueling the storm's rapid intensification.
Landfall is expected Tuesday, with authorities fearing extensive damage.

Milei’s party, La Libertad Avanza,…

items.title: Donald Trump won in Argentina
items.standfirst: With his support, Argentinian President Javier Milei can now chainsaw the country into greatness.
items.content: With his support, Argentinian President Javier Milei can now chainsaw the country into greatness.

items.title: Javier Milei hails ‘tipping point’ as his far-right party wins Argentina’s midterm elections
items.standfirst: Result falls short of giving Milei a congressional majority but surprises many analysts after series of scandalsThe party of Argentina’s far-right president, Javier Milei, has won Sunday’s midterm elections after a campaign in which Donald Trump announced a $40bn bailout for the country and made continued aid conditional on the victory of his Argentinian counterpart.With more than 99% of ballots counted, La Libertad Avanza secured 40.8% of the nationwide vote, in an election widely seen as a de facto referendum on the self-styled anarcho-capitalist’s nearly two years in power. The Peronist opposition, Fuerza Patria, secured 31.7%. Continue reading...
items.content: Result falls short of giving Milei a congressional majority but surprises many analysts after series of scandalsThe party of Argentina’s far-right president, Javier Milei, has won Sunday’s midterm elections after a campaign in which Donald Trump announced a $40bn bailout for the country and made continued aid conditional on the victory of his Argentinian counterpart.With more than 99% of ballots counted, La Libertad Avanza secured 40.8% of the nationwide vote, in an election widely seen as a de facto referendum on the self-styled anarcho-capitalist’s nearly two years in power. The Peronist opposition, Fuerza Patria, secured 31.7%. Continue reading...

The Peronist opposition secured approximately 31.7 percent of the vote.

clusters.title: At 92, world’s oldest president wins Cameroon’s election again
clusters.neutral_headline: Cameroon President Biya Wins Eighth Term in Election
bullet_summary: His main rival, Issa Tchiroma Bakary, who claimed victory based on his own tally, denounced the result and said civilians outside his home were fired upon
Paul Biya, 92, said to have won 53
The country’s constitutional council said Biya had won 53
The country's Constitutional Council announced that the 92-year old won 53

items.title: At 92, world’s oldest president wins Cameroon’s election again
items.standfirst: Paul Biya has won reelection, the country's top court said Monday, after days of protesters' clashes with security forces left at least four people dead as opposition supporters demanded credible results.
items.content: Paul Biya has won reelection, the country's top court said Monday, after days of protesters' clashes with security forces left at least four people dead as opposition supporters demanded credible results.

items.title: Cameroon's 92-year-old president wins controversial eighth term
items.standfirst: Paul Biya retains his title as the world's oldest head of state, in an election marred with violence and allegations of fraud.
items.content: Paul Biya retains his title as the world's oldest head of state, in an election marred with violence and allegations of fraud.

items.title: Cameroon's president re-elected at 92
items.standfirst: The world's oldest head of state, Paul #Biya, 92, extended his more than four-decade rule, securing an eighth term in #Cameroon's presidential poll - results which his rival swiftly rejected. On October 26, four people were killed in #clashes between security forces and supporters of the opposition in the economic capital Douala.
items.content: The world's oldest head of state, Paul #Biya, 92, extended his more than four-decade rule, securing an eighth term in #Cameroon's presidential poll - results which his rival swiftly rejected. On October 26, four people were killed in #clashes between security forces and supporters of the opposition in the economic capital Douala.

items.title: Cameroon’s Paul Biya re-elected for 8th term amid protests
items.standfirst: Cameroon’s 92-year-old president Paul Biya has been re-elected for an eighth term with 53.7% of the vote, according to the Constitutional Council. His main rival, Issa Tchiroma Bakary, who claimed victory based on his own tally, denounced the result and said civilians outside his home were fired upon. Protests erupted in several cities, leaving four people dead and over 100 arrested, as authorities banned public gatherings and dismissed allegations of fraud.
items.content: Cameroon’s 92-year-old president Paul Biya has been re-elected for an eighth term with 53.7% of the vote, according to the Constitutional Council. His main rival, Issa Tchiroma Bakary, who claimed victory based on his own tally, denounced the result and said civilians outside his home were fired upon. Protests erupted in several cities, leaving four people dead and over 100 arrested, as authorities banned public gatherings and dismissed allegations of fraud.

items.title: World’s oldest serving head of state declared winner in Cameroon election
items.standfirst: Paul Biya, 92, said to have won 53.66% of vote after volatile two weeks since election when opponent claimed victoryPaul Biya, the world’s oldest serving head of state, has been declared the winner of Cameroon’s election, granting him an eighth term that could keep him in office until he is nearly 100.The country’s constitutional council said Biya had won 53.66% of the vote, while his former ally turned challenger, Issa Tchiroma Bakary, got 35.19%. Continue reading...
items.content: Paul Biya, 92, said to have won 53.66% of vote after volatile two weeks since election when opponent claimed victoryPaul Biya, the world’s oldest serving head of state, has been declared the winner of Cameroon’s election, granting him an eighth term that could keep him in office until he is nearly 100.The country’s constitutional council said Biya had won 53.66% of the vote, while his former ally turned challenger, Issa Tchiroma Bakary, got 35.19%. Continue reading...

items.title: Biya declared victor of Cameroon election: Why deadly protests broke out
items.standfirst: Paul Biya, world's oldest leader at 92, has won eighth term as president. Opposition supporters say election was stolen.
items.content: Paul Biya, world's oldest leader at 92, has won eighth term as president. Opposition supporters say election was stolen.

items.title: Cameroon: President Paul Biya secures 8th term with 53% of vote
items.standfirst: Paul Biya extended his 43-year rule on October 27, securing an eighth term as president of Cameroon. The country's Constitutional Council announced that the 92-year old won 53.7 percent of the vote, beating rival Issa Tchiroma Bakary who came in second with 35.2 percent. FRANCE 24's Indira Ayuk has the details from Yaounde.
items.content: Paul Biya extended his 43-year rule on October 27, securing an eighth term as president of Cameroon. The country's Constitutional Council announced that the 92-year old won 53.7 percent of the vote, beating rival Issa Tchiroma Bakary who came in second with 35.2 percent. FRANCE 24's Indira Ayuk has the details from Yaounde.

items.title: Cameroon re-elects world's oldest president
items.standfirst: The world's oldest president has again won the vote in Cameroon, despite violent clashes ahead of the election.
items.content: The world's oldest president has again won the vote in Cameroon, despite violent clashes ahead of the election.

ai_summary: Paul Biya, 92, won Cameroon's presidential election for an eighth term.
The election was marred by violence and allegations of fraud.
Opposition supporters protested the results, leading to clashes.
The Constitutional Council declared Biya the winner with 53.66 percent.
Protests erupted in several cities, resulting in arrests and deaths.

clusters.title: Ten people go on trial in Paris for online harassment of Brigitte Macron
clusters.neutral_headline: Trial Begins in Paris for Online Harassment of Brigitte Macron
bullet_summary: Reported by Guardian World, Al Jazeera, France24 and others

items.title: Ten people go on trial in Paris for online harassment of Brigitte Macron
items.standfirst: Trial is latest phase in legal battle against false claim that French first lady is a man named Jean-Michel TrogneuxTen people have gone on trial in Paris charged with online harassment of Brigitte Macron – the latest phase in a legal battle on both sides of the Atlantic against the false claim that the French first lady is a man named Jean-Michel Trogneux.The French trial comes after the president, Emmanuel Macron, and his wife filed a defamation lawsuit in the US at the end of July, in connection with a rumour amplified and repeated online that Brigitte Macron was born a man. Continue reading...
items.content: Trial is latest phase in legal battle against false claim that French first lady is a man named Jean-Michel TrogneuxTen people have gone on trial in Paris charged with online harassment of Brigitte Macron – the latest phase in a legal battle on both sides of the Atlantic against the false claim that the French first lady is a man named Jean-Michel Trogneux.The French trial comes after the president, Emmanuel Macron, and his wife filed a defamation lawsuit in the US at the end of July, in connection with a rumour amplified and repeated online that Brigitte Macron was born a man. Continue reading...

items.title: France trial opens for 10 accused of online harassment of Brigitte Macron

items.content: Judge says defendants caused ‘deterioration’ in French First Lady Brigitte Macron’s ‘physical and mental health’.

items.title: How did online rumours that Brigitte Macron was born male go viral?
items.standfirst: Ten people went on trial in France on Monday, accused of the online harassment of Brigitte Macron, who has been hounded for years by rumours that she was born male. How did the conspiracy theory gain such traction in France and beyond?
items.content: Ten people went on trial in France on Monday, accused of the online harassment of Brigitte Macron, who has been hounded for years by rumours that she was born male. How did the conspiracy theory gain such traction in France and beyond?

items.title: Brigitte Macron harassment trial opens in Paris
items.standfirst: Ten people are on trial in Paris for spreading false rumours about Brigitte Macron’s gender and personal life. The case, involving influencers and online figures, comes as the Macrons also pursue legal action in the US over similar attacks spread by far-right media.
items.content: Ten people are on trial in Paris for spreading false rumours about Brigitte Macron’s gender and personal life. The case, involving influencers and online figures, comes as the Macrons also pursue legal action in the US over similar attacks spread by far-right media.

items.title: France: Ten on trial for spreading malicious rumours about First Lady Brigitte Macron
items.standfirst: Ten people are on trial in Paris for sexist cyberharassment against Brigitte Macron, accused of spreading false rumours about her gender and personal life. The case comes as the Macrons also pursue legal action in the US over similar online attacks amplified by far-right influencer Candace Owens. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris-Trent has more from Paris court.
items.content: Ten people are on trial in Paris for sexist cyberharassment against Brigitte Macron, accused of spreading false rumours about her gender and personal life. The case comes as the Macrons also pursue legal action in the US over similar online attacks amplified by far-right influencer Candace Owens. FRANCE 24's Catherine Norris-Trent has more from Paris court.

items.title: Ten go on trial over claims Brigitte Macron is a man
items.standfirst: Ten people accused of cyberbullying Brigitte Macron are going on trial in Paris after allegedly making "malicious" comments claiming the French first lady is a man.
items.content: Ten people accused of cyberbullying Brigitte Macron are going on trial in Paris after allegedly making "malicious" comments claiming the French first lady is a man.

items.title: Trial begins for 10 accused of sexist cyber-bullying of Brigitte Macron
items.standfirst: The defendants are accused of spreading unsubstantiated claims over Mrs Macron's gender and sexuality.
items.content: The defendants are accused of spreading unsubstantiated claims over Mrs Macron's gender and sexuality.

ai_summary: Ten people are on trial in Paris for online harassment of Brigitte Macron.
The trial concerns false claims that the French First Lady is a man.
The Macrons are also pursuing legal action in the United States.
The case involves influencers and online figures spreading rumors.
The judge stated the defendants caused harm to Brigitte Macron's health.

items.standfirst: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said President Donald Trump told him the US and Malaysia will deal with US tariffs on semiconductors “at the appropriate time.”
items.content: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said President Donald Trump told him the US and Malaysia will deal with US tariffs on semiconductors “at the appropriate time.”

items.title: Has Trump's 'peace deal' solved the Thailand-Cambodia dispute?
items.standfirst: Donald Trump has claimed to have ended another war, this time between Thailand and Cambodia. But what does this latest agreement actually amount to?
items.content: Donald Trump has claimed to have ended another war, this time between Thailand and Cambodia. But what does this latest agreement actually amount to?

items.title: Trump oversees Thailand-Cambodia ceasefire signing as Asia tour gets under way
items.standfirst: Trump has begun a five-day trip to Malaysia, Japan and South Korea, his first visit to the region since taking office in JanuaryDonald Trump has overseen the signing of a ceasefire agreement between Thailand and Cambodia on the first day of an Asia tour where he will seal new trade agreements and hold a crucial meeting with Xi Jinping.The US president arrived in Malaysia on Sunday before the Asean summit in the capital, Kuala Lumpur. At a ceasefire ceremony in front of a sign that read “Delivering Peace”, the Thai prime minister, Anutin Charnvirakul, and his Cambodian counterpart, Hun Manet, signed an expanded ceasefire deal related to a deadly five-day conflict in July. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump has begun a five-day trip to Malaysia, Japan and South Korea, his first visit to the region since taking office in JanuaryDonald Trump has overseen the signing of a ceasefire agreement between Thailand and Cambodia on the first day of an Asia tour where he will seal new trade agreements and hold a crucial meeting with Xi Jinping.The US president arrived in Malaysia on Sunday before the Asean summit in the capital, Kuala Lumpur. At a ceasefire ceremony in front of a sign that read “Delivering Peace”, the Thai prime minister, Anutin Charnvirakul, and his Cambodian counterpart, Hun Manet, signed an expanded ceasefire deal related to a deadly five-day conflict in July. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: President Donald Trump kicked off his trip to Asia on Sunday by presiding over the signing of an enhanced ceasefire agreement between Thailand and Cambodia that he helped mediate earlier this year.
items.content: President Donald Trump kicked off his trip to Asia on Sunday by presiding over the signing of an enhanced ceasefire agreement between Thailand and Cambodia that he helped mediate earlier this year.

ai_summary: Donald Trump oversaw the signing of a ceasefire agreement.
The agreement was between Thailand and Cambodia.
Trump claimed to have ended a conflict between the nations.
The signing occurred during Trump's Asia tour.
The deal relates to a previous five-day conflict.

items.title: Lithuania to shoot down smuggler balloons, shut Belarus border crossings
items.standfirst: Lithuania says balloons disrupting air traffic are sent by smugglers transporting contraband cigarettes into the EU.

items.title: Lithuania says it will shoot down smuggling balloons from Russia’s ally Belarus
items.standfirst: PM blames Alexander Lukashenko for not stopping ‘hybrid attacks’, which closed Vilnius airport four times last weekEurope live – latest updatesLithuania’s prime minister has authorised the shooting down of smuggling balloons that cross the border from Russia’s ally Belarus, calling them “hybrid attacks” in an echo of the term used to describe Moscow’s destabilisation efforts.Incursions by balloons carrying contraband cigarettes prompted the Nato and EU member state to close Vilnius airport four times last week and shut its border crossings with Belarus temporarily. Continue reading...

clusters.title: 'Trapped and terrified': Genocide warnings after RSF's Darfur advance
clusters.neutral_headline: Fears Grow in Sudan After RSF Claims El Fasher
bullet_summary: The group said on Sunday that it had seized control of the army’s main base in the city in Darfur, where famine was declared in a displacement camp last year
Reported by NPR News, Guardian World, France24

items.title: 'Trapped and terrified': Genocide warnings after RSF's Darfur advance
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces claim they've seized the Sudanese army's last base in El Fasher, Darfur — trapping hundreds of thousands and stoking fears the country could split in two.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces claim they've seized the Sudanese army's last base in El Fasher, Darfur — trapping hundreds of thousands and stoking fears the country could split in two.(Image credit: Lynsey Addario)

items.title: Grave fears for civilians after Sudanese paramilitary claims capture of El Fasher
items.standfirst: RSF says it has seized control of army’s main base in Darfur, home to famine-stricken displacement campFears are growing for hundreds of thousands of civilians trapped in El Fasher, Sudan, after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces said it had captured the city, which it has been besieging for more than a year in the country’s civil war.The group said on Sunday that it had seized control of the army’s main base in the city in Darfur, where famine was declared in a displacement camp last year. It then released a statement saying it had “extended control over the city of El Fasher from the grip of mercenaries and militias”. Continue reading...
items.content: RSF says it has seized control of army’s main base in Darfur, home to famine-stricken displacement campFears are growing for hundreds of thousands of civilians trapped in El Fasher, Sudan, after the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces said it had captured the city, which it has been besieging for more than a year in the country’s civil war.The group said on Sunday that it had seized control of the army’s main base in the city in Darfur, where famine was declared in a displacement camp last year. It then released a statement saying it had “extended control over the city of El Fasher from the grip of mercenaries and militias”. Continue reading...

items.title: RSF claims El-Fasher takeover as Sudan conflict worsens
items.standfirst: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have released videos claiming their takeover of the Sudanese army headquarters in El-Fasher, the last army stronghold in Darfur. While RSF soldiers celebrate, local army-allied fighters say fighting continues. If the city falls, all five Darfur state capitals would be under RSF control, amid an 18-month siege that has caused severe starvation and displaced millions in Sudan’s two-year war.
items.content: The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) have released videos claiming their takeover of the Sudanese army headquarters in El-Fasher, the last army stronghold in Darfur. items.title: Red Cross accompanies Hamas in search for bodies of Israeli hostages in Gaza
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Red Cross acts as ‘neutral intermediary’ to recover hostages’ remains in areas under Israeli controlThe International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) accompanied members of Hamas inside areas of Gaza still under the control of the Israeli military to facilitate the search for the bodies of Israeli hostages, an official from the ICRC told the Guardian.Under the US-brokered ceasefire, which took effect on 10 October, Hamas is required to return the remains of all Israeli hostages as soon as possible. In exchange, Israel has agreed to hand over 15 Palestinian bodies for each Israeli. Continue reading...

Trump said he would not meet with Canada "for a while".
The ad campaign featured a quote by Ronald Reagan.

ai_summary: Lawsuits against banks with Epstein ties may shed new light.
Survivors of Jeffrey Epstein have demanded justice for years.
Ghislaine Maxwell was found guilty of sex trafficking.
Experts say proving banks enabled Epstein will be difficult.
Maxwell was sentenced to 20 years imprisonment.
